r
15
90
e Queen; to M
r
[Bodley .]
of
Ostend
,
S
r

Norreis
entertain., Of

, w
th
more
[.]

/

.

page.lettertext:
fol.343r
Belgia: 1590. De
c
22 Decem
b
To M
r
Bodly
By the Queene:
Elizabeth R
Trusty and welbelovid, We greete you well. Although we heare that c
r
tain
parsons are appoynted to be sent from the States there in outward apparance being
acc
o
panyed w
t
sondry marchant
to c
o
playne of the arrest
& prises made as they will
alledge, of theyr good
, upon the Seas,
But
Yet as you doo write that they have a transcripte
of such aunswers as they have devised, to the proposicions there offred by
Thomas Wilk
& you in July Last, w
ch
you doo doubtfully write that they will not be knowen to have,
Therfore untill the same shall be notified unto us by them, we meane not to take any
knowledge therof. And so having occasion to write to them about c
r
tain oth
r
matters
very needfull for the tyme, We doo not in o
r
l
re
s shew any apparence to know that
they have such a
n
sweres, But do breefely touche o
r
lack of satisfaction in all thing
rec
o
mended to them, as by the copie of o
r
l
re
s you shall see. And for the present thing
to be demaunded of them, we do allso but sommarily touche the same, referring the
furder declaration of the particularities to be by you deliveed. Therfore we
will that yo
u
shall first consider well, of these causes heerafter following, And
they w
t
out delaye, deliver o
r
l
re
s to the
States generall
, & use yo
r
form
r
diligence
& w
t
all ernestnes meete, for the causes, to obtayne of them the thing
required.
You shall repete to them how careles we have founde them to have bene of long
tyme in satisfyeng of the necessary demaund
for the defence & ma
y
tenance of Ostend,
a Town (as in o
r
l
re
is expressed) as needefull and as serviceable to be well
keep
kepte
as any town under their rule, And how often yo
u
have moovid them in
S
r
John
Conways
tyme to give ayde to the defence of that Town against the Sea, & allso for
the fortifieng of it against the ennemy, yo
r
self can tell, And so yo
u
shall not fayle
but laye the particularities therof plainly before their faces, And though their
fault
passed can not be revoked, but
that
the same are now no more to be c
o
tynued
yo
u
may shew them in what valiant manner
S
r
Edward Norris
the present
gouverno
r
hath defeated the Ennemyes approches to their greate dishono
r
& losse,
and to the intent he may c
o
tynue this good fortune against the ennemy, Who
doutlesse
fol.343v
Belgia: 1590: Decemb
r
doutlesse though it shall be costly to them, will seeke revenge, We therfore require
the States to consent & to give order that twoo band
of footemen of o
r
forces may
be w
t
all speede sent thither, to increase the strength of that garrison, And that allso
they doo send provision of powder & munition, wherof the Gouverno
r
writith they have
greate lack, And you shall ernestly presse them to delay no tyme for perfo
r
mance
heerof. wherof allso yo
u
shall make
S
r
Frances Vere
privie, that out of
e nomber
in his charge, twoo band
may be made ready to be sent to Flusshing, to be shipped
to Ostend.
You shall allso lett them knowe that where they have ordeynid S
r
Edward Norris
to be Gouverno
r
of that Towne, and have promised him interta
y
mente due for the
same, for any thing that we can heare, he hath not hitherto had any penny. A thing
very strange, to c
o
mytt the charge of such a Towne, w
t
out a
n
swering any thing for
his entertaynment, he having no mor than the bare Wages of a capten of a band
And that payed by us, as all the rest of the meanest captens have. This yo
u
may note
to them as an indignitie to be c
o
mytted by them taking upon them the gouvernem
t
of
wholle co
n
treys. But we have hard that they meane to gra
n
te him his allowance
out of the Revenues of the Towne, w
ch
are nothing, or els out of such c
o
tributions
as the co
n
try will offer to be freed from the garrison. But that being not as yet
accorded, as it seemith, he is yet w
t
out any allowance at all. And as to the
c
o
tribution offred by the co
n
trey, w
ch
the Gouverno
r
sayth the States wold have his
assent unto, We can be well c
o
tent that the same be accepted by him, So as his
entertaynment by payed out of the same, And that the woork
against the Seas
& the necessary fortifications be therw
t
allso defrayed, And that powder & all
munitions be in lyke manner therby supplyed.
There is allso one oth
r
thing necessarily to be obtaynid of them, that is, That
they shall be c
o
tent, whensoever o
r
Gouverno
r
of Flusshing shall finde
cause to doubte of som attempte to be made by the Ennemy for surprising of
that
fol.344r
that town, as of Late by secr e t intelligence we have bene infourmid that the ennemy
hath had such an intention, in such case he may be permitted to require from S
r
Frances Vere to have one or twoo band
brought thither, only for the tyme of doubte.
And to this end, you shall procure their assent, And as the manner is a Potence
or conducte for the quyet & safe passage of them thither. And therof you shall
advertise both
S
r
Robert Sidney
and S
r
Frances Vere, so as they may agree how
& when to have the said nombere when tyme shall require. These matteres both for
Ostend & Flusshing, You shall prosecute w
t
all ernestnes requisite both w
t
the States
generall & w
t
the Counsayle of State, affirming plainly, that we shall not take
eyther a denyall or a delaye heerof in good parte, but shall make acc
o
pte of them as
unwo
r
thy of o
r
favoure paste, and much Lesse of any the lyke heerafter.
For other matteres c
o
teynid in yo
r
late l
re
s, you shall understand o
r
mynde, by the l
re
s
of o
r
Tresorer of England
.
Given under o
r
Signet at o
r
Manno
r
of
Richmond the xxij
th
day of december in the yeare
1590
and of
o
r
Raigne the xxxiij
th
yeare.
